sentence: In an effort to free itself from the flooring scandal, Lumber Liquidators Holdings, Inc.LL announced that it has decided to stop the sale of laminated flooring products imported from China.

Lumber Liquidators has been in troubled waters since a report aired on "60 Minutes" on Mar 1, which accused the company of selling Chinese flooring laminates containing formaldehyde levels that do not meet California emissions standards.
Last month, the company announced that it would suspend the sale of these products until the board committee finished its assessment of its sourcing compliance program.
It has finally decided to stop selling these products altogether.
In May, the company's CEO Robert.
M. Lynch had unexpectedly quit without any explanation.
Lynch's resignation came after CFO Daniel Terrell's decision to step down.
Earlier this week, the company also terminated and replaced its Chief Merchandising Officer, William K. Schlegel.
The controversy could not have come at a worst time for Lumber Liquidators.
The company's performance over the last four quarters is nothing short of dismal with the results missing the Zacks Consensus Estimate in the trailing four quarters by an average of 80.6%.
In the most recent quarter, the company posted a negative surprise of 293.3%.
Analysts observe that things are going to get worse before they get better at Lumber Liquidators and see a cloud of uncertainty looming over the company's remaining fiscal performance.
Other stocks which might gain from Lumber Liquidators' trouble include Lowe's Companies Inc. LOW , The Home Depot, Inc. HD and Tile Shop Holdings, Inc. TTS .
